column4: Can I install ubuntu on a logical partition and make that my only os?
yes
cool. thanks for answring,

I have Suse right now and I want to use ubuntu.  I do not want to loose my /home and /usr/local so I am re-paritionning right now and my two primary partition I do not want the installer to touch (not format).  Easy?
the livecd install always formats it/s own / root.. but not other partitions on the drive. as in seperate /home or /var..
So... all I have to do is select "manual" on the partition screen and specify the logcial partition I am building right now as the root and the other partition will not be touched?
correct.  it will only force you to format whatever partition you chose for /root
Nice!!!!
if you have enough for a second swap partition you can do that as it will eliminate one issue for hibernate/suspend etc.
What do you mean? What issue?

if you have enough for a second swap partition you can do that as it will eliminate one issue for hibernate/suspend etc. If you dual boot, and hibernate one os and boot the other, you may be overwriting something in swap you wanted..
If I do not want to dual boot, will I have this issue?
no
I do not want to dual boot. I want to replace Suse.
may I suggest one thing...
PLEASE :)! :)

if you install full working system on a single partition you will not have any issuses as home will be inside root,  it is then a known working system so you can redirect from a working system to your old home as I think that is what you want to do eventually
yes, that is what I want to do.  Once the install is finished, I will change it so that the home partition is using my existing/old partition.
just pointing that option out,  It is easy to point to your old home during the install, but if there is a conflict you dont get a working system
thanks, it is appreciated.
you sound like you have a good understanding of the process.  it will go fine
I have been using linux for 5+ years now, but my first time with ubuntu.  Tried many distro before, but I am not an admin, I am a user.
welcome to ubuntu
